24036806.review:
This is my first review ever, so you can imagine my opinion before I even begin. Very minor spoilers ahead.

I loved this. I don't read many visual novels, mostly because their content doesn't interest me much, but something about this one caught my interest. So I tried it. And I'm glad I did.

The writing was emotional, the artwork was fantastic and the music was perfect in every part. I loved all of the characters and they were all (for the most part) well written. The H-scenes were optional, but they were slotted in perfectly I never would have noticed they weren't there all the time.

What did I not like?

1) The numerous spelling and grammer errors throughout; incorrect words, repeated words, missing words, etc. These will likely be fixed in updates, but at the time of this writing, they were pervasive enough to warrent a lost point.

2) The lack of character development of the three side characters Mariah, Tess and Joseph. Honestly, I found them far more interesting than the two main characters and would have liked to learn more about their pasts and just plain have them play more of a role. Marina as well. I felt she didn't get anywhere near the amount of development that Amber got.

3) Lack of choice. I know the story is about the romance between Amber and Marina, but I would have liked the option to romance Mariah instead. I just didn't like Marina that much. I thought it might be an option when Tess mentions Mariah has never had a boyfriend, and then the scene where Amber and Mariah get drunk in the motorhome, but it was just a tease.

4) The H-scenes felt short and rather sub-par. They are optional, so they didn't factor into my review score, but I was a bit disappointed with them.

Overall Score: 8/10

I really liked it and want more. Maybe a sequel that focuses on the dynamic-trio?

Well done, devs. I salute you.

24034471.review: Despite my recomendation, I was actually quite on the fence about whether to recomend this game or not. The characters are cute, albeit not really fleshed out, and I enjoyed their interactions; however, as previously mentioned, they were not really that complex of characters and I actually enjoyed the side trio much more than the two main characters. I was also none to impressed with the plot jumps which seemed scattered throughout the story. One such instance is when the main character, Amber if I remember correctly, states that they both have secrets they do not want to tell each other and in the next instance both know each other secrets, but the viewer is left none the wiser. The BGM is also quite good, but it tends to cut out quite a lot which disrupts the story's ambiance. Taking all this into consideration, I would usually not recomend this game, but I enjoy yuri games and I also quite liked the side trio. It's a good yuri game with likeable, albeit not expanded upon, characters that could use refining.

23955954.review:
This is a kinetic novel, so if you're in it for the choices, look elsewhere. Likewise, the treasure hunt mystery is fairly underplayed and mostly just serves as setup for a road trip story.

That being said, it's a very well executed road trip story that gets across the unique mood and wonder of that particular genre while our heroines make their way through the American west. All characters are written very likeable and usualy manage to escape being stereotypes, despite being painted with a fairly broad brush. 

The romance itself is easily the best I've seen in a yuri visual novel so far. It develops with a slow, natural pace and feels awkward and fragile at times, like fledgeling relationships do. Aside from one little misstep of dipping into melodrama a bit too much, it is very genuine and heartfelt.

As for the technical aspects, the artwork ranges from decent to pretty good, capturing landscapes with as much variety as it does the characters. They really made use of sprite moving and scaling in ren'py to make everything look more varried and dynamic than it usually does in low budget visual novels. The music too is mostly instrumental and sticks to the background, adding to the mood and atmosphere instead of getting annoying. I usually mute the music at some point in a VN, here I made it through 10 hours without feeling that impulse once.

23882180.review:
My first VN I've played through completely. 

My first initial thought at first seeing this on Steam was, 'oh this is cute'. Later on I was gifted the game from one of my friends on Steam, and of course I thanked them. :) 

Now I don't want to spoil anything, but when I first played it, as I said above, it was my first VN, so I didn't know what to expect. I saw text, but that was it, so I was a bit dissapointed at first, not the games fault of course, I didn't think VN's were all text based, (silly me). But I've come to appreciate them more now after having went through this one.

I actually thought the story wasn't as long as I thought it was when I first started it up, so I read through most of it as fast as I could, not actually paying much attention to the story itself, later on I realized how much I started to actually get into the story, so I went back a bit at the start of the story in order to understand the story much better, and glad I did. I enjoyed this VN a lot more than I thought I would from the start. I got many emotions from it, sadness, happiness, I even giggled a bit every now and then, as I progressed through the story more and more, I found myself wanting more and more, hoping it wouldn't end too soon. I believe it's worth the money given how much it took me to complete it. I haven't went back and tried the extra option though. 

So aside from the fact that this was my first VN. Do I regret it? Nope, not at all. Do I reccomend it? Absolutely. The developers did a good job in my opinion getting the player feeling the right emotions at the right time. And it was one of the most cute stories I've read in a while now too. Thumbs up from me! Hope to see more like this in the future if possible. :)

23874836.review:
I want to preface this by saying that [b]Highway Blossoms[/b] is not a visual novel, not in the sense most people would expect. It does not feature branching paths or story-bending choices; there is one route only, and you will not waver from its path. In this sense, it is more of a kinetic novel than a visual novel.

That is not at all to say that the game doesn't deserve to be played. It's a cute tale of love in the strangest of places, of heartbreak, and of a deep sadness. I found myself experiencing many of Amber's emotions as she did; the art and the writing combined to create a beautiful tale. I was profoundly sad when it ended, not because the ending didn't satisfy me, but rather that I wanted [i]more[/i]. I felt an emptiness inside me because it was over and done with, and I'm really hoping AlienWorks writes a sequel. If not I may have to dust off the old fanfiction hat and give it a try myself.

My only real complaint is that the game could do with proofreading; there are a few instances of sentences structured incorrectly, or words repeated where they shouldn't be.

All in all, if you're looking for a fun tale and have a little money to spare, take a chance on [b]Highway Blossoms[/b]. If you're looking for a well-paced yuri romance, take a chance on [b]Highway Blossoms[/b]. If you're looking for a game where your choices matter, though, look elsewhere.

Highway Blossoms is an exception to the pandering Market many find on steam (Though there is nothing wrong with pandering to your audience at times)

It isn't ground breaking new.. Its nothing you haven't seen before.. Mixing the Plots of the Road Journey and Coming of Age Romance... But perhaps that's why its enjoyable.

The story is just as much made by the Two main characters; their trials tribulations and their triumphs as it is made by the background of 'Americana' and its fantastic OST; that fits right in with the themes and enhances them especially the 'Americana vibe' . And of course the story is not your usual school setting - Taking place in the American South West.

For an OEL the series has Far above average art; very easy on the eyes. And the overall 'back ground art' well not perfect is certainly not lacking either.

Highway Blossoms has an All Audiences and an 18+ - If you are 18 or over I certainly recommend adding the patch to obtain the full uncensored story. The Adult scenes in this story are not there for the sake of being there; they feel like they should be there; They fit with the story and its heroines and continue the good flow of the VN.

I always enjoy a good Visual novel and some good Romance and this is both and im happy to recommend it.

Also as a final note; there is added 'extra' content to allow for some small replay value to the VN once completed.

23804204.review:
I don't exactly have a lot of experiance with VNs, but I've played the Ace Attorney series to death, and I enjoy over-analysing fiction in general so I guess that counts for something.

If you're expecting the usual Japanese anime or yuri tropes, get ready for something widly outside your comfort zone, because the artstyle is literally the only thing about this VN that has anything to do with Japanese culture -- with only one signfigant exception: Tess; a deadpan loli character.
The discontinuity between the artstyle and the western settign can be jarring at first, but you'll have plenty of time to adapt after you get sucked into the plot. 

Highway blossoms is about a nineteen-year-old wandering hermit girl who meets up with lovable ditzy sheltered girl with a sweettooth who just so happens to be the exact opposite of her in every way, naturally making her a perfect foil/deuteragonist.
And you know what they say about opposites right? You know where this is going. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

The romance itself is flawlessly excecuted. It takes all the appropriate twists and turns and comes off as entirely authentic. I can't explain exactly why it's so good without spoiling everything, so I might was well end the review here.

My only nitpicks are that there still seem to be some niggling proofreading issues that the devs haven't sorted yet, and that you could make a drinking game out of the number of times a character rolls thier eyes. 
I know it's effective at showing how the character is feeling, but seriously is there really no other way of expressing exasperation or passive-agressive contempt?

Whatever, it's an emotional ride, so check it out.

23783032.review: I've loved anime, manga, and VNs for a few years now, but I'd never thought that one day I'd be reading a Yuri VN with treasure hunting in the vastness that is the American West. The Americana themes and the setting were executed extremely well, and I felt fairly engrossed in it the whole way through. Halfway through, however, I kind of felt disillusioned with the characters, and kinda felt like they were just to plain and simple, but the game immediately shifted to telling their backstories and developing them, and it was wonderful. I'd recommend this VN to anyone who can appreciate a good romance, it's one of the least "anime" VNs I've ever playted as the Eastern influences are really not very present. Thanks Alienworks for making this short and sweet VN that really anyone can enjoy, I look forward to your future projects.

23780602.review:
Let me get this straight. This is a KINETIC VISUAL NOVEL. You cannot alter the course of the storyline via decisions or QTE. 

That being said, you have no reason to. 

While the game is relatively short and sweet, it has everything you would want in a good romance novel, visual or paperback. And unlike most other VNs, it features a bevvy of contributions from other artists, adding stylistic but palatable changes to character appearances and backgrounds every now and then. The music is beautiful, the plot is easy to follow, and the inclusion of achievements makes absolutely no sense for such a straightforward game. 

In short, it's virtually the opposite of a Sakura game. It's the sort of game you would play for the story plot over the oppai plot. 

And for those of you who prefer the latter? Don't fret! The developer made downloading the adult patch free, easy to download and quick to install. It doesn't multiply the ecchi level to unreasonable levels, but you get two romantic sex scenes and a number of notable (and sometimes hilarious) changes in dialogue. 

In short, it compares to the Sakura franchise the same way inFAMOUS 2 compares to inFAMOUS. Half as long, twice as bright. 

P.S. NEVER trust an RV going 85 in a 70. Treasure hunters are scary. And always order the kids' size pancakes at waffle houses. ENJOY!

23771918.review:
+ Art: Scene CGs tend to differ from the sprites more or less, and the quality isn't consistent either, but some are very nice.
+ Music: [strike]If it was sold, I'd buy it.[/strike] Just didn't notice earlier.
+ Story & cast: Most of both.
+ Length: Being a slow and attentive reader, it took me 25+ hours to finish, with save loss reset then skipping, and reporting issues. Just starting Goofball Mode.

- Lack of choices: I don't mind that it's a kinetic novel, but besides the added value, it could have helped a bit with the last of the negatives.
- Bugs: Typos which can affect immersion, and some serious issues, which hopefully get fixed over time.
- Uneven pace: I don't complain because there are slower parts. I complain because some things didn't get that much time, and that there is no epilogue, because of not assuming there'll be another episode.
- Deus ex machina moments and aspects of the story. Only one really glaring, the others are less unrealistically convenient.
- No voice acting: Like choices, it'd just be huge plus, if it was done well.
- Amber: Merely my own opinion, as is this whole review. See below if you're curious.

My last point may cause disappointment to some other players, but obviously didn't for many. For the whole experience I still recommend this kinetic novel, and thank the effort put into it.

For those who want to read more, before buying the game, and want to know why Amber is on the negative side for me (no real spoilers):

[spoiler]It's Amber's story, she narrates it, we can also read her thoughts, and hers only. Until more than half of the story, she remained interesting and potentially likable for me, because she had yet a lot of space to extend into as a person. However approaching the end, I started liking her less and less, nearly disliking her by the end. After I slept on it, I could summarize what I believe bothers me about her as: She is pretty much like a guy, rather than a girl, and thinking about it, maybe a surprisingly reduced amount of changes would be needed to switch the protagonists' gender. This opinion may come from that her qualities and flaws are such that I'd sooner associate with a guy than with a girl. More details in the next section, for those who finished the game or insist on more details to decide.[/spoiler]

For people who finished the game or don't mind heavy spoilers:

[spoiler]Until Amber got close enough to Marina to start teasing her, she remained unknown enough for me to anticipate more kindness and caring from her. From then on, though, I only discovered that she didn't have much of those left hidden, instead there were an overwhelming amount of flaws to discover:
- A very low empathy level.
- Insensitivity, in the form of teasing that may really hurt, and is only fun for who teases. Could also compare to the behavior of some children, that some people don't grow out of, I imagine because they don't realize how it feels for whom it's said to, leading back to lack of empathy.
- Lack of consideration and attention. E.g., despite supposedly being in love with her, she admittedly didn't pay much attention to Marina's tastes, or attempted to find out more through conversation, like what she can't eat. It is also hard to believe the idea of buying more clothes for Marina only came to her mind at the end. It may have been a production decision, to avoid different outfits, along with shopping scenes, but story-wise it still came off like that for me. It was on my mind for a while by then, but at least when they decided to look for all the treasure together, it would've been natural to think of that necessity in my opinion. Not to mention not buying a phone in the end, at least for Marina, to replace her old one. They could've bought it together, and it would've indeed been very useful very soon...
- Lack of appreciation of Tess's cute aloofness. This is a joke, but true.
- Having difficultly expressing and discussing her emotions. She'd rather end up talking to a guy – or her rival in his absence – about her problems, than to the very person they affected the most, and who is supposedly also the most important right then to her. Should be praised for not cheating on her to confirm how little she meant?

Her qualities are generally on the masculine side, which isn't a bad thing, just feels unbalanced when added together:
+ Great driving skills.
+ Sense of direction.
+ Ability to intimidate.
+ Affinity mostly – or only – to practical skills.

Some of these could be attributed to her upbringing and her grandfather's heavy influence. The intention might've been to make her more like a butch, too. Even if there are such reasons, I think the lists above, along with her
* choice of clothes
* considering it her job to fulfill a guardian role
* not being conscious of her body
* objective stance towards relationships
* almost complete lack of concerns when it comes to liking other girls or being together with one,

would make it rather easy, as far as the writing is concerned, through changing references, and only a few events, to adapt it to a male protagonist instead. Most of the inner monologues and actions shouldn't even be touched, that's how it seems to me, looking back. This may bother a few more people, who expect a bit different female protagonist.

I quite early thought of how nice it'd be to read the story narrated by Marina, because Amber seemed more like whom I'd romance, but I'm not sure I wouldn't have changed my mind in the latter half, even if that was possible. What prevented me most from liking Amber was how she dealt with the consequences of her actions, after her night in the desert and reuniting with Marina. Additionally, the reason why she tried to send her away could've been – rather than protecting Marina – to avoid an unwanted relationship, when she only looked for a replacement and some comfort after losing a loved – the most loved – one of hers. Ultimately the concern is the same, but in the process Marina was definitely hurt, yet after they reconcile, Amber only tells about how happy she is, without any sense of guilt, or thinking about how she should make amends.

Moving on from Amber, something else I started missing as the story progressed, just as Amber did her tackling hugs, were Marina's hopping and bouncing sprite movements, her specialty from early on. Although such movements were still mentioned sometimes in text, Marina seems to have lost quite a bit of her cheerfulness during the time with Amber, which isn't a too positive change.

Quite a few signs could indicate their relationship won't continue too well over time, but the lack of epilogue entrusts this to everyone's imagination. The ending is happy, but on a hill right after severe ups and downs.

It's a pity we don't get to know more about the trio's circumstances, not like Amber ever tried.

Finally, my order of the characters according to how much I liked them, and why:

Marina (Really the best person we get to know more about in the story, despite her flaws. She didn't steal any car accidentally.)
Tess (Amber really wouldn't want a honest and calm little sister like her?)
Joseph (Takes care of Mariah and Tess, despite being a slacker.)
Cassi (Was nice even after her disappointment.)
Station Attendant (As far as we get to know him, he's helpful.)
Dino (Harmless.)
Mariah (She showed more consideration than Amber, never mind how uncharacteristically.)
Amber (She really doesn't deserve Marina unless she can change.)
Linda (She [b]is[/b] harmful.)
Mr. Jumbo (Please don't exist.)

Disqualified: Howard and the rest.[/spoiler]

This is not a cheap VN by any means. The story, visuals and soundtrack are of consistent quality. The story wasn't out of this world, but it was good and heartwarming. There is a good attention to CGs, that are way better than most indie light novels. One of the problem I've had with VNs in the past is the story drawing for too long and dying down at some point. This really isn't the case here; its pacing is really well executed and the story for the most part feels totally believable. You will get attached to the main characters, especially Amber. The soundtrack is simple but appropriate. I love the ending song.

23713782.review:
I got the game via Family Sharing, but that's not an important factor as to the enjoyment of the game and my review.

The game, for it's $10 price, may seem a bit of a steep price for a "6 or so hours of reading" game, but it's not. I spent 9 hours on my first playthrough of the game, and found it quite enjoyable. I expect to spend around 8 hours in goofball mode, which is an additional mode that's unlocked once you've finished the game.

This game, simply put, is amazing. This was my first Visual Novel ever, and I'm glad to have set such a high standard for the genre. Several elements tie this game together; the visual aspects, the general feel, and the music being key factors. The character development was very well done, leaving me with a quirky opinion of the characters, because I felt like I knew them by the end of the game. The story was very intricately put together, with the romance and drama being both cute and cringe-worthy at the same time (in a good way.)

The developers are very active, and keep frequent tabs on the discussions. They have released several patches that fix both minor and major bugs. An additional patch adds the full content to the game, adding several erotic sequences that adds to the emotional level of the game.

The visual aspect of the game is pure gorgeous. The art style kept me enthralled with the game, and I hopped on whenever I had a free moment. The characters are expressed through minor changes of their facial expressions, or by physical attire and arm movements. The characters also move around a bit, leaving the bare idea of animation.

The world that the game describes through pure text, accompanied with the visuals, leaves an impact of a well-thought-out description for an area. I felt like I was personally there in all the sequences and individual scenes.
One of the most important parts of the game was the music. The music was perfect, spot-on, flawless. The music, throughout the game, tied in very well with the sequences, and even added to the humourous sequences, with music cutting off at seemingly random moments to emphasize a point made in the text, or with the visual movements of the characters. I intend to buy the soundtrack when I can.

One of the most important elements of any game is the story-telling, and the emotional involvement.
The story of Amber, throughout the game, left me both breathless and tearing up. I might be the exception, but the game had me drawn in, from start to finish. I'm not really sure how to express the depth of the characters, and the emotions they go through, but it feels like you, the player, are going through the same trials as the characters are.

There are a few minor things that the game struggled with, and these tended to slightly draw me out of the emotional eggshells that the characters made me feel like I was walking on. Throughout the game, there are minor typoes that don't affect the story. There was only one that had me baffled for a minute as I tried to piece together what the purpose of that specific line in the text was. The conspicious lack of a change of clothing is a bit unusual, to say the least.

The game is well worth the money. Congratulations to AlienWorks and Sekai Project on this masterpiece of a game.

23705432.review:
Between otaku-pandering Japanese productions and amateur OEL wannabes, there's a lot of trash in the visual novel genre. Plenty of gems, too, but wading through the refuse to find one is an art in itself.

[i]Highway Blossoms[/i] is one of those exceptions.

That's not say it's a revelation. Outside the American Southwest setting, [i]Highway Blossoms[/i] is little more than an average coming-of-age romance meets road film starring two young women, each with their own complementary personalities and existential crises -- time-tested cliches at their best.

But that doesn't make it any less compelling. What it lacks in novelty, [i]Highway Blossoms[/i] more than makes up for it with romantic charm and superb tact, filled to the brim with saccharine ups and heart-wrenching downs that hit in all the right places but never once feel out of place; even the H scenes impress, the subtlety and tenderness unexpected coming from a lesbian romance written by two men.

The art is by all means above-average for an OEL novel, but for me, aesthetically out of place. A more realistic sense of stylization with just a pinch of East Asian flair would have worked better given the heavy Americana vibe, something the original score captures perfectly -- dusty guitars and contemplative minimalism serve as the ideal mood setters, arguably the biggest highlight to be found here.

Then again, I'm a sucker for a good love story, and that's exactly what [i]Highway Blossoms[/i] does best: touching romantic exposition via mixed media and an excellent reminder as to why I enjoy this genre in the first place.

23681923.review:
Developed by AlienWorks and published by Sekai Project onto steam. Highway Blossoms is a short yuri story set in American Southwest. It takes place after an old gold rush miner’s journal is discovered, supposedly detailing and containing clues about where he hid parts of his stash.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story starts of with Amber, who couldn’t care less about the treasure let alone know about the treasure existence. Wandering the Southwest in an inherited motorhome, she mourns the loss of her grandfather, totally unaware of the hunt taking place around her. Not until she meets Marina, a young hitchhiker wandering through the deserts of New Mexico. Things start to pick up from there after she lets Marina get a ride from her and gets to know about the treasure.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
For the visual aspects I think it is generally well done and the art style is very pleasing to the eye and it gives off a nice ambiance around the visual novel itself with the use of vivid colors. I relatively enjoy the music in Highway Blossoms though I would like to state that at certain parts of the story no music was used and It got a little awkward.

[h1]To sum up[/h1]
Would I recommend Highway Blossoms? As a huge fan of Yuri genre it would go against my nature to not recommend Highway Blossoms. Highway Blossoms is well worth your time if you are into yuri and like a American theme.

[url=https://azusantiara.com/2016/06/21/highway-blossoms-review/]Click here for full review with images and more![/url]

23664929.review:
Highway Blossoms was an enjoyable read, if not without its share of faults. The lead characters, Amber and Marina, are both likeable, their interactions together often cute, and many of their quips genuinely amusing. Having the story set not only in the United States but not in a high school was a breath of fresh air. Although I can’t say I’ve played a huge number of visual novels the premise of road trips is interesting and unlike anything I’ve seen since Katahane.

That being said, the story is at its strongest when it is not being a discount National Treasure. The treasure hunt plot felt unnecessary in the long run, and the story could have easily been a sightseeing tour on the way to California, finding the beauty in nature and growing closer without the motivation of money (still, I can see the treasure hunt being a metaphor and the actual treasure not being anything gold). There is also some drama in the tail-end of the story that is resolved far too quickly and cleanly. 

Despite these faults I can still recommend this to anyone looking for a yuri-themed visual novel. The music was above average compared to anything else I’ve heard in the genre, and despite there being no voice acting the characters are highly expressive even thorugh static sprites, which often move around the screen to give the impression of animation. The artwork for the sprites is quite good, but the CG art is inconstant, some of them giving Amber noticeably shorter hair than she has.   

Pros:
+Great characters 
+Good music
+Unconventional setting

Cons:
-Story feels unfocused at times
-Inconsistent art

23660846.review:
This may look like your usual yuri VN, but between the setting, the rock-flavored soundtrack, and the more mature (in the general sense of the word, though of course in the adult version there's that too) feel, Highway Blossoms isn't quite so usual at all outside the anime art style (though even that at least is very [i]good[/i] anime-style art).  Even the main relationship feels pretty fresh for the most part, though there's some of the usual moments in it.  In general, it looks good, sounds great, and feels almost perfect, knowing when to be silly and when to be more grounded and serious.

It's not perfect; the pacing feels off at times, ocassionally rushing through or dragging a bit, and there were a few bugs and missing features that they've thankfully been working hard to fix.  There's a few other tiny things here and there that I didn't like or didn't agree with, but nothing else really worth mentioning.

(Having played it both with and without the developers' adult patch, I'd like to note that the scenes cut for this version include at least one that's a major part of the story; not having it doesn't break the plot, it's still easy enough to figure out what happened, but it does make things feel disjointed for a bit.  As long as you're not too uncomfortable with it I'd recommend getting it from the game's website just because of that.)

23642722.review:
The store page said this game took 6 hours to beat, and I did it in exactly that (With the adult patch installed) and did so in a single sitting. I was hooked to this VN from start to finish, and while that could be because the characters look, act and feel exactly like my relationship, I'm pretty sure it's because it's a great bundle of fun. 
It might not be the longest, but it all fits together incredibly well. The graphics/aesthetics are beautiful and fit together really well, the soundtrack, while slightly irritating to start, quickly became very fitting, and the entire thing was amazing. It was well polished, and I only found two typos in the entire thing. All but one of the side characters had sprites too, which I really liked (whereas longer games such as IMHHW and Everlasting Summer didn't have) and so I feel this game was truly loved - and it makes you love it too.
There are no choices, however, it is a linear VN, so that's worth noting (There is no actual gameplay). With the story, there was a good half an hour where I thought "This is a bit odd" but I can't complain because it's plausible - the characters could fit that scenario, so it's all good. There is also [strike]no gallery[/strike] [i](There is now a gallery)[/i] or jump options on the menu, so if you wanna skip through it to replay certain bits and such, then you can't really, though the skip option is very quick, and the easy way to scroll through previously read scenes is very nice. It would have been nice if there was a better way to understand the keys, (like middle mouse button to hide the ui and see the picture, and V activating text to speech). But honestly these things don't matter to me. Just click, appreicate, and play the whole thing!
The story is mostly about their cute/sweet relationship, and not really about the gold rush thing. I mean, thats a huge thing, but it's not so much of a challenge, but the situation for our plot to be told. The relationship story is very sweet, and there are some good references and funny moments.
A couple achievements involving settings didn't popup until I looked at the gallery after beating the game, but that was not an issue really - since anyone hunting for achievements would beat the game.
This is really just a very relatable, very sweet, very cute, and very polished yuri VN, of moderate length, and it's definitely worth it's price. 
For those questioning the adult content, it wasn't much, it wasn't forced, and it complimented the story very well, though I think you'd be okay without it too if you're disgusted by that sort of thing. It's not too intense though, but enjoyable none the less :^ )
The relationship development didn't seem stretched, I think it was realisitic, and not obvious that it would happen from the start. As opposed to everything pushing them together like this is a Hollywood romcom or something, things aren't always perfect for them, and just hnng. 
Gosh, I really don't know what to say at this point, everything I've said sounds like a criticism but I honestly can't think of more flaws other than what I have said. If those won't bother you, buy this! It's excellent!!
I'd ditch my cs:go team again should there be a sequel!

23629565.review:
Welp, this was a rather unexpected surprise! I may be a bit stingy at buying new games, but passing up a newyuri visual novel is something I have found hard to do in the past, and today was no exception. I loaded Highway Blossoms up expecting it to be a simple, feel good, story, with well drawn visuals, and an experience a bit on the short side. What I got was exactly that, but a bit more.

To begin, I must confess that I have visual novels a bit hard to get into in the past. Even highly regarded ones have been left with unfinished savefiles and a yet to be fulfilled promise of completion. It's not a lack of quality that got me, but just a slowness to get into things, and a bit of the unknown regarding the payoff once the story does get going.
I was hoping for this one to possibly warm me up to the genre; and I have to admit, It most likely has succeeded. Regardless though, this a review from someone that isn't particularly well versed in the world of visual novels.

Besides the just the yuri, the Mojave desert location was an interesting one and defiantly helped draw me in a bit.
The Mojave can be beautiful, and they did a great job representing this. Even the more generic background scenes are fun to look at, and when one gets to the set-pieces, one realizes the artists really knew what they where doing.
They are beautiful scenes, with just the right amount of lighting  animation to add to the story without distracting. The characters are well drawn, and appealing to look at. The animation used is effective in the conversation scenes, with just the right amount of drawn images to keep it from becoming repetitive. The devs don't overstep themselves the more movement heavy scenes, and the way they leave it to the imagination is well executed. TLDR - It looks great, with many a cute character many a doing cute things in a very well drawn, pretty world.

The story isn't too bad. It isn't nessisarly the most believable thing, and has a few plot holes here and there, but it serves it's purpose as a way to drive the interactions forward. It was goofy at times, and did have a slight feel of
being contrived, but I was easily able to put the oddness aside and enjoy it. This is probably due to how well the characters fit into the grand scheme of things. The story did do a great job at giving you the feeling a following 
two folks going on the more interesting side of adventure; the kind with that entails a large place to explore and nowhere fast to be. The pacing was a bit strange though. It feels like the characters mention certain locations and such, and then by obligation the story would follow up to that location later on. It left a slew of mostly unrelated feeling events only connected by the characters themselves, and little else. Highway Blossoms' story at times also felt like it was following a flow chart. An event would happen that would feel out of character, just to simply add some drama. Or they would go to an exotic location, just because. It would be a bigger problem in something else, but it is redeemed by what I think is the strongest part of this experience, the character interactions.

From a writing perspective, the characters personalities are fleshed out, relatable, and interesting. Their backstories are not completely revealed, but instead hinted at throughout via character interactions and the the main 
character's observations. Their personalities are also well defined as well, and all that, in conjunction with some extremely good writing, equal some fantastic and believable interactions. The conversations go from being genuinely 
funny, to sad, to heartfelt, to relaxed, and it all flows extremly well. It is alot of fun watching these extremely well designed characters do things, and react to the situations that they are thrown into. I was whole hearteningly
rooting for the obvious yuri parring not only because I enjoy the characters, but also due to how well the two interacted. I love all the characters, even if the MC is a bit of a dingus. 

Highway Blossoms isn't the longest experience, but an enjoyable one. It gives a good sense of adventure, while still giving a great romance story to boot.

23625884.review:
First review and I don't really know how people do this so....
*Grammar is awful get over it*

TL;DR I don't know if it's worth 10 bucks but, It's pretty good. If you just want to relax and zone out to a game, this does the trick.

I have not yet finished the game. I'm a little over 6 hours in and, I'm writing this as if I'm in the future and have finished the game. I'll put some edits at the bottom to fix stuff as I complete the game.

Overall: This game ended up being pretty ok. I mean the story isn't going to win any awards (no offence), but the characters made the story enjoyable. It was a little slow at times but, durring treasure hunts the pace would pick up, and I'd find myself spam clicking through the scenes to see what would happen. The game so far <-------(I actually haven't finished it yet) is on a steady course gathering steam as I feel shit will probably go down soon. If you do want to buy this game, I'd say wait until some more reviews come out as, I don't know If I can accurately give you a decent rating on it overall.

Art: "9/10" The art was wayyyy better than I thought it would be, I mean I thought this game would be a long shot but it ended up looking better than a lot of the huge publisher Japanese stuff, which is a feat in itself coming from a prettymuch no-name studio (with like 5 people working on it). The art was good however, it lacked in quantity. The backdrops were very well drawn however when like 90% of your scenes are in a motorhome you'd think they would have some angles that allowed you to see the backdrop outside of the vehicle more, instead you get a bunch of detailed shots of the inside of an old motorhome. (Of course driving through the desert there probably wouldn't be much to look at anyway) I say the art's a solid 9/10. Not as much as I wanted but, what was there was good.

Story: "6/10" I'll be honest I had to force myself to click through some of this game the reason being, it lacked depth. I mean the game is tagged casual, which fits it perfectly however, I find myself wishing it had a more powerful story. It's the kind of story that would make for a great short animated series however, having to read it all out takes away from the cutness of the driving in an RV for hours. The story starts to pick up an hour or two in, and grows more and more enjoyable as it goes on. I did find myself having to take a break every once and a while though, I wasn't expecting this to be a huge page turner. FIX: (It gets a lot more dramatic in the second half)

What else is there?

Characters: "7/10" The characters are unique and refreshing throughout the story. Not crazy deep but, I didn't want deep characters in a game like this. They fit well and I don't think there's much more to say.

Sound: "7/10" I wrote sound, but what I really mean is the music. If you didn't know this game has no naration; I didn't know but I also didn't read the discription. Again with the whole "it worked pretty well thing." I feel like this vn would be pretty weird if there was voice acting. It's written in a more western style, and good english speaking voice actors are hard to come by. I'm glad they didn't throw some shitty voice acting into the mix.

Music: "7/10" The music worked well with most of the scenes though, some could use a change of pace. The songs would occasionally die out and then not start up for a few min which left it feeling empty, if that makes sense.

I'm sure there's some other things but this has already gone way longer than I had planned so I'm ending it here.

Semi-Final verdict: 11/10 "it's ok"

EDIT: I forgot to mention this game says it's yuri and.. that's like sorta true but you need to patch it to get the extra content/dlc bonus ecchi shit, whatever you want to call it ya pervs. This is steam afterall.

EDIT #2: It did pick up in the second half. Much dramas happend and it's longer than I thought it would be. So far I would give this game a solid 7/10 but, I've been known for giving high scores so take it with cup of salt. OH more yuri stuff happend in the second half, like a lot more. I don't really know how to feel after playing this game but, if the discription catches your eye, I'd check it out. Two thumbs up!

EDIT #3: I'll post the actual final verdict once I finish the damn thing.

39357702.review:
[h1]Simply one of the best visuals novels i've played so far[/h1]

[u]Interesting story of a young girl coping with a recent loss[/u], riding her motorhome along a highway to visit a music festival, she was meant to go to with her passed away granddad, meeting another girl along the way. Starting of a little weak with their adventure of finding parts of a hidden treasure, you soon get to know the characters and their motivation, always following the main protagonist's thoughts, which make up a big part of the story, making you always stay in touch with the protagonist and being able to follow her, giving the game a lot of credibility, which finally plays out after the first third of the game, when their relationship intensifies and emotions come into play, making up her mind about her loss and how she approached the situation, how she treated her new friend and what their true feelings are.

The two main protagonists' [u]character traits are also really likeable[/u], with one being rather handsome and sweet, trying to comfort the other and being there for her and the other one making stupid jokes, being sarcastic and thoughtful, not yet having found her new place in the new situation, she has been thrown into.

Despite the well done story, which also features way more gameplay time than the average visual noval (took me [u]about 8 hours to complete[/u]), the game also has some [u]beautiful CG scenes[/u], several of them even animated with little light effects.

There are [u]no decisions to be made however[/u], so those you are looking for a game to create their own story with their own decisions will be disappointed. But the story and the amount of content make up for that entirely, in my opinion, as most visual novels' decisions don't influence the story that much (or even at all) anyway.

There is an [u]R18 patch available[/u] for two extra scenes.

[b]For those into visual novels, or those who wanna try one out this is a sure must-buy and is absolutely worth the full price.[/b]

38985627.review:
A short and sweet romantic VN that's well worth the sale price. I was expecting a cute, fluffy lesbian treasure-hunting roadtrip narrative, and was pleasantly surprised that the game packaged that with a touching story about a woman coming to terms with loss while finding new love. I have some minor complaints about the treasure-hunt itself (it, along with its associated side-characters, is so implausible and silly that it kind of clashes with the rest of the relatively down-to-earth narrative), but the rest of the story stuck with me long after those complaints faded. The character art is good, but a little inconsistent across CGs and character portraits; the art really shines, though, in the backgrounds, which (together with the music) do a fantastic job of setting the scene for this story. Seriously: that landscape art is gorgeous! 

P.S. There's a ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) patch if you're into that but, honestly, I can't see it working very well with this art style.

39491022.review:
Review originally posted [url=https://www.backlog-assassins.net/posts/27mzqob/]here[/url].

8/10

Highway Blossoms is a cute, wonderful, genuine love story between Amber, a grieving young woman who travels the country in a motorhome, and Marina, a girl fresh out of high school who is on the hunt for treasure. It fills a niche that achingly needs to be filled - stories about same-sex relationships that aren’t fetishizing, and that are just like heterosexual romances, except for the genders of the protagonists. Amber and Marina’s relationship has its ups and downs, but as the two young women grow closer there is just so much budding love and happiness it is truly a balm for the soul.

That’s not to say there isn’t conflict - Amber and Marina embark on a treasure-hunt expedition where they compete against another motorhome and their inhabitants - their rivals - on who will find the gold first. As the story progresses and as the relationship takes center stage, the conflict isn’t ‘oh no! we’re gay! gay is bad! we’ll get heckled for holding hands in the street!’ but rather Amber is terrified she’s undeserving of Marina’s love because of how broken Amber is as a person, for not being able to take care of her Grandpa well enough. It’s escapist fiction of the best sort, where homophobia doesn’t exist, and it’s like a weight off the shoulders.

The game isn’t perfect - the writing isn’t the type that really gets me in my chest, and unfortunately the well-drawn sprites and the lively kinetic way they move about result in the sprites being scaled-down and looking somewhat pixellated and aliased for the vast majority of the novel, making the art look of lesser quality than it is. But there were times I choked up, and I felt really happy in the end.
